data.title: Inconsistent Background Colour on Second Display
data.body: ### Prerequisites * [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following: * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/ * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages ### Description Different shades of colours rendering in blocks in the background of the editor window on a second display. Primary display: Secondary display: ![screen shot 2017-05-24 at 16 00 44](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/439662/26412756/b23ed5c8-40a1-11e7-85c7-0c282290ea8e.png) ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Open a document in Atom. 2. Drag the Atom window to a second display. 3. Expand the window until the the blocks of colours are visible. **Expected behavior:** Background colour should be consistent (as it is on the primary display). **Actual behavior:** Background colour renders in blocks of different shades. **Reproduces how often:** 100% ### Versions OS: macOS Sierra 10.12.6 Beta (16G8c) Atom: 1.17.0 Electron: 1.3.15 Chrome: 52.0.2743.82 Node: 6.5.0 apm: 1.17.0 npm: 3.10.5 node: 6.9.5 x64 python: 2.7.10 git: 2.11.0 Atom: 1.18.0-beta0 Electron: 1.3.15 Chrome: 52.0.2743.82 Node: 6.5.0 apm: 1.18.1 npm: 3.10.10 node: 6.9.5 x64 python: 2.7.10 git: 2.11.0 ### Additional Information Hardware: - MacBook Pro (Retina, 15-inch, Early 2013) - NVIDIA GeForce GT 650M 1024 MB - Intel HD Graphics 4000 1536 MB The behaviour is much easier to see when using dark themes but is visible on all themes I have tested. I was seeing the exact same behaviour when using the `Caret` markdown editor which also runs on `Electron`. I reported the issue and they fixed it in [version 1.14.0](https://github.com/careteditor/caret/releases/tag/1.14.0). See the [conversion](https://storify.com/jasonroyle/conversation-with-jasonroyle-and-careteditor) that I had with them (with examples).

data.title: Some modified files are not saved when quitting Atom (reproduce systematic)
data.body:
Hello

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When I quit Atom, some unsaved file are not saved and no prompt is open for me to choose to save or not. Some other have a prompt, depending how I open the file (see below)

### Operation ONE

> touch tmp
* open Atom
* drag tmp into Atom
* modify tmp
* type Command-Q
* I expect a prompt to save the file tmp, there isn't.
> more tmp => tmp is empty
* reopen Atom and drag tmp again
* I expect to see an empty file, but the modified unsaved file is displayed (waw!)

### Operation TWO

* Do exactly the same, but instead of dragging tmp into Atom, open it with recent files (package open-recent 5.0.0) : the prompt is asked before quitting which is what I expect !

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

1OO%

### Versions

Atom    : 1.17.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

### Additional Information

MacOsX 10.12.4

data.title: SemVer / BC policy for Atom editor
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    [X] Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    [X] Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    [X] Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    [X] Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    [X] Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When 1.17 came out the treeView.mainModule.createView(); was replaced (AFAIK) with treeView.mainModule.getTreeViewInstance(); - this is from https://github.com/olmokramer/atom-permanent-delete package.

This is Minor version that should not introduce a BC change - I would like to propose what Symfony team does. When you want to delete/remove the function call because new one was introduced:
1. Delete the body of the function only.
2. Add deprecation notice with example on how to fix the code and comment code for removal in 2.0.
3. Include new function call in the body of "old" code (so new code is running), and all "legacy" requirements like parameters passed or other function calls that need to be invoked (in case of code separation into more detailed functions).
4. Allow everyone to update without issues until 2.0

Please see: http://symfony.com/doc/current/contributing/code/bc.html

This should in my view enhance quality as non working packages get abandoned by people/users potential contributors as they don't work. Deprecations are "annoying" so and are more likely to be fixed also you're not breaking the software for many users that way and give devs time to figure out new ways of handling issues.

I know that on the other hand you're "allowing" to use deprecated code that way, but that will have to change when 2.0 is defined. You will probably just reach that point faster and it will be better for us all.

### Steps to Reproduce
NA

**Expected behavior:** All packages for ^1.0 work but throw deprecation error.

**Actual behavior:** Packages break.

**Reproduces how often:** 100% on BC break

### Versions

ALL

### Additional Information

It works great with Symfony - one can always be sure they care about their software and that it will continue to work on "obsolete" packages, also note that there are versions that merge new functionallity in 2.0 with BC promise from 1.0 so last 1.x version has same functionality as 2.0 and throws deprecation errors but still works. This is a major feat and allows everyone to prepare for even major changes without breaking the application.

I feel this is THE solution for reliable software releases. I hope it can be achieved by Atom team.

data.body:

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/

    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

If Atom has no open windows and just the menu bar interface.  Clicking File > Open... or File > Reopen Project does nothing.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Close all windows, but still leave Atom in an open state.
2. Click File > Open
3. That's it.

**Expected behavior:** The file dialogue opens.

**Actual behavior:** Nothing. The command silently fails.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

Atom    : 1.17.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

apm  1.17.0
npm  3.10.5
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.10
git 2.11.0

### Additional Information
I've tried seeing the log out of the Console app, but it receives nothing.  Tested the same scenario on 1.18 and it produces the same issue.

data.title: Grave accents causing visual problem with multiline selection
data.body:
### Prerequisites

Reproduced it in `--safe` mode. (Didn't have time for the other steps).

### Description

Cursors are misplaced after selecting multiple lines for the first time and typing in grave accents (`). As far as I can tell it is just a visual bug as the next characters are placed correctly behind the accents.

![foo](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11627131/26406077/87e5e334-4097-11e7-9350-b284fac8a459.gif)

data.title: Flickering Screen - odd GPU issue
data.body:
I have a sort of non-standard GPU multi-screen setup with an older GPU on one of my dev machines, and I was having issues with Atom flickering uncontrollably at start.

Discovered that turning off one screen in the monitor settings then turning it back on alleviated the flickering issue for me. 

Just thought it might be interesting or helpful to some Atom user / dev out there :)

data.title: Atom 1.18.0 - Multiple Remote Push URL's
data.body:
### Prerequisites
* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Not detecting remotes if multiple URL's are set for the same remote.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Add an additional push URL
```
git remote set-url --add --push origin git@github.com:username/repo
git remote set-url --add --push origin git@github.com:username/repo2
```

2. Verify it worked
`git remote -v`
```
origin	git@github.com:username/repo (fetch)
origin	git@github.com:username/repo (push)
origin	git@github.com:username/repo2 (push)
```
3. Now try to do a push from inside of Atom and you will see

> Note: No remote detected for branch. Cannot push because there is no remote named "origin" for which to create a remote tracking branch.


**Expected behavior:** 
It should work the same as running the command:
> git push 

Which will push it to both just fine.

**Actual behavior:**
It doesn't allow me to push at all.

**Reproduces how often:**
100% of the time. Interestingly enough though, if I only add a second remote url **after** I have already loaded in the repo, it will continue to allow me to push - until i close and open atom or add the repo again (at which point it detects changes the error comes).

### Versions

1.18.0-beta0
